moves.1. c4: I've always like the English Opening. White will aim to control the light squares in the center of the board.
moves.1... c5: Black responds symmetrically. The game could easily transpose into a variation of the Sicilian at this point.
moves.2. Nc3 g6: Black plays for a flank attack, keeping his center Pawns in reserve for the moment. Very Hypermodern-like.
moves.3. Nf3 Bg7: I, too, hold back my center Pawns. Black follows up with the completion of the fianchetto.
moves.4. g3 Nc6 5. Bg2: If Black were to develop his King Knight, the position would be entirely symmetrical. I'm not afraid of playing for a draw and trying to squeeze a win in the endgame.
moves.6. e4: ...and I parry. Black still has the option of going for symmetry.
moves.6... Nge7: Now the game really begins, as symmetry is broken.
moves.7. O-O f5: Black wants to seize a central advantage...
moves.8... Nd4: Black offers to trade Knights. This would plant his Pawn at d4, but I feel I get sufficient compensation by being able to place my Queen Knight at d5 after the exchange.
moves.9. Nxd4 cxd4: This capture leaves me with a Queen-side advantage in the potential endgame. I would have used the e-pawn instead.
moves.10. Nd5 O-O: Black completes his development. The Knight on e7 is vulnerable to the pin...
moves.11. Bg5: The pin, they say, is mightier than the sword. I'm not sure how Black can escape without material loss. 10...Nxd5 was probably a better alternative, to be followed by 11...O-O.
moves.11... Rf7: The best Black can do now is end up down the Exchange.
moves.12. Nxe7+: The logical follow-up. I was expecting 12...Rxe7 13 Bxe7 Qxe7, which would have left me with an exchange up but still some work to do to secure the win.
moves.12... Kf8: Catastrophic. Now the killer discovery seals things quickly.
moves.13. Nxg6+: Black resigns, as he loses his Queen if he plays on.
